text: By Jon Munshaw.

report_title: Threat Source newsletter (May 26, 2022) BlackByte adds itself to the grocery list of big game hunters
chapter_title: Threat Source newsletter (May 26, 2022) BlackByte adds itself to the grocery list of big game hunters
text: Welcome to this weeks edition of the Threat Source newsletter. Given the recent tragedies in the U.S., I dont feel its appropriate to open by being nostalgic or trying to be witty lets just stick to some security news this week.

report_title: Threat Source newsletter (May 26, 2022) BlackByte adds itself to the grocery list of big game hunters
chapter_title: The one big thing
text: The

report_title: Threat Source newsletter (May 26, 2022) BlackByte adds itself to the grocery list of big game hunters
chapter_title: The one big thing
text: BlackByte ransomware group

report_title: Threat Source newsletter (May 26, 2022) BlackByte adds itself to the grocery list of big game hunters
chapter_title: The one big thing
text: uses its software for its own goals and as a ransomware-as-a-service offering to other criminals. This actor and its affiliates have infected victims all over the world, from North America to Colombia, the Netherlands, China, Mexico and Vietnam. BlackByte updated its leak site with a new design and new victims and is still actively exploiting victims worldwide.

report_title: Threat Source newsletter (May 26, 2022) BlackByte adds itself to the grocery list of big game hunters
chapter_title: Why do I care?
text: Talos has been monitoring BlackByte for several months and we can confirm they are still active after the FBI released a joint cybersecurity advisory in February 2022. Additionally, BlackByte is considered part of the big game ransomware groups, which are targeting large, high-profile targets, looking to exfiltrate internal data and threatening to publicly release it. Like similar groups, they have their own leaks site on the darknet.

report_title: Threat Source newsletter (May 26, 2022) BlackByte adds itself to the grocery list of big game hunters
chapter_title: So now what?
text: It's more important now than ever to have a multi-layered security architecture to detect these types of attacks. The adversary is likely to manage to bypass one of the other cybersecurity measures, but it is much harder for them to bypass all of them. Theres also a ton of IOCs you can add to any block lists that

report_title: Threat Source newsletter (May 26, 2022) BlackByte adds itself to the grocery list of big game hunters
chapter_title: So now what?
text: we have listed on our blog

report_title: Threat Source newsletter (May 26, 2022) BlackByte adds itself to the grocery list of big game hunters
chapter_title: So now what?
text: , as well as previous Snort rules and ClamAV signatures to protect against this threat actor.

report_title: Threat Source newsletter (May 26, 2022) BlackByte adds itself to the grocery list of big game hunters
chapter_title: Other news of note
text: The ongoing battle between the Conti ransomware gang and Costa Rica continued this week, with Costa Ricas president saying his government is at war with Conti. Meanwhile, Conti seems to have dissolved and is now broken up between several sub-groups, though Conti actors continue to release statements on Costa Rica. This massive ransomware attack on a countrys government has other smaller states worried they could be the next ransomware target. Many services in Costa Rica have been inoperable for weeks after the Conti attack. (Tech Monitor, The Verge, TechCrunch)

report_title: Threat Source newsletter (May 26, 2022) BlackByte adds itself to the grocery list of big game hunters
chapter_title: Other news of note
text: Several state-sponsored actors in Europe and the Middle East are buying the Predator spyware from commercial surveillance company Cytrox to spy on Android users. Researchers from Google say theyve spotted these actors operating in Egypt, Armenia, Greece, Madagascar, Cte dIvoire, Serbia, Spain and Indonesia. The firm sold the spyware along with exploits for zero-day vulnerabilities in the Chrome web browser and Android operating system, which are now all patched. (Google Threat Analysis Group, Gizmodo)

report_title: Threat Source newsletter (May 26, 2022) BlackByte adds itself to the grocery list of big game hunters
chapter_title: Other news of note
text: Zoom patched an XMPP vulnerability chain that could lead to remote code execution, along with several other security vulnerabilities in the virtual meeting client. A security researcher discovered an attack chain in which an attacker sends messages to the target over Zoom chat with the XMPP protocol no user interaction is required. If successful, the attacker could then execute remote code on the targeted machine. Other vulnerabilities Zoom disclosed this week included an issue that could allow an adversary to send user session cookies to a non-Zoom domain, which could allow for spoofing. (Security Week, Google Project Zero)
